title: WCAS POLI_SCI 390-0-22 Special Topics in Political Science

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Prof. Brian Harrison "LGBTQ Politics & Identity" Winter 2016
In the past 20 years, there has been a meteoric and unprecedented shift in attitudes in the United States toward lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) individuals and their rights, yet many obstacles to LGBT equality remain. This course will include a broad discussion of identity, public opinion, its formation, and how it is affected by the news media; contemporary attitudes toward LGBT individuals in the U.S. context; a history of the LGBT movement; and a focus on institutional constraints on issues like marriage equality, adoption rights, employment non-discrimination, and transgender equality.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Attendance at first class required; no p/n option; abc grading only

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
As a result of this course, students will be able to:

Overall Course Objectives
1. Analyze the progression of LGBT rights in the context of public opinion and U.S. institutions
2. Think about social justice and social movements in the context of LGBT identities and politics
3. Critically evaluate arguments and/or counter-arguments to contemporary debates surrounding LGBT rights

Specific Learning Objectives
1. Read controversial and difficult material objectively and critically.
2. Communicate how the LGBT movement changed over time and the social and cultural significance of those changes
3. Engage with different approaches to the study of public opinion, identity politics, and LGBT politics
4. Construct a narrative about identity, sexual orientation, and public opinion in the United States over the past several decades

2. David Eisenbach, 2006. Gay Power: An American Revolution. New York: Carroll & Graf.
